question: Question_07_(i)
statement:
A particle is moving in the (x,y)-plane along the curve $y = x^{2}$. As
it passes through the point P = (2, 4), its \emph{y} coordinate changes
at a rate of 8 units/sec.

i) Find $dx/dt$ at the instant the particle is at the point P.
sols:
The question is asking us to find the rate of change of the variable x.
(i.e: We want to solve for dx/dt). Using implicit differentiation and
the equation $y = x^{2}$ we will derive a value for these quantities as
follows:

\begin{align*}
\frac{d}{dt}y &= \frac{d}{dt}x^{2} \\
\frac{dy}{dt} &= 2x\frac{dx}{dt} \quad \rightarrow \quad \frac{dx}{dt} = \frac{1}{2x}\frac{dy}{dt}\end{align*} From the information about the rate of change of y at the
point P, we make the appropriate substitutions in the equation to
determine dx/dt:

\begin{align*}\frac{dx}{dt} = \frac{1}{2(2)}8 = 2 \quad \rightarrow \quad {\color{blue}\frac{dx}{dt} =2}\end{align*}
hints:
Remember that the rate of change of a quantity $z$ is just the
derivative of that quantity with respect to time, (i.e: dz/dt).
